title: 108_hr1015
content: The "Thurgood Marshall Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of 500,000 1 dollar coins with specific specifications. The coins will contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper, weigh 26.73 grams, and have a diameter of 1.500 inches. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Silver for minting will be obtained in accordance with the law. The design of the coins minted under the Thurgood Marshall Commemorative Coin Act will symbolize his tenure on the Supreme Court. Each coin will feature the coin's value, year of issuance, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Supreme Court Historical Society, Thurgood Marshall's family, and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the Thurgood Marshall Commemorative Coins will symbolize his tenure on the Supreme Court and will be chosen in consultation with the Supreme Court Historical Society, Thurgood Marshall's family, and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design will also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The Thurgood Marshall Commemorative Coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single US Mint facility within a 1-year period after the Act's enactment. The coins will be available for sale. The Secretary will sell coins issued under the Act at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design/issuance costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a discount. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. The surcharges from the sale of coins under this Act are paid to the Historical Preservation Committee of the Supreme Court Historical Society for collecting and preserving the history of the Supreme Court, including research, acquisition of objects and documents, and preservation of historical items for the benefit of the people of the United States. The Comptroller General of the United States conducts audits. The Comptroller General of the United States can audit the books and records of the Supreme Court Historical Society related to expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment is given by a qualified institution.
